title: With an exoneree hospitalized, majority of Md. panel wants plan for payments in place by Oct. 16
text:
Hubert James Williams in Washington on July 25. He was hospitalized after being assaulted Saturday while sleeping on a park bench. (Bonnie Jo Mount/The Washington Post)

Under increasing public pressure to compensate five wrongly convicted men who spent decades behind bars, Maryland’s Board of Public Works is weighing whether to give itself a deadline to act.

Two of the three board members said Wednesday that they should have a plan in place by Oct. 16 for deciding how much to pay the men, one of whom, Hubert James Williams, is homeless and was hospitalized after being assaulted Saturday while sleeping on a park bench.

Williams’s pro bono lawyers have twice asked the board to approve a $35,000 interim payment to help him secure stable housing and substance abuse treatment. The board, which oversees major state contracts and spending, did not act on that request, nor mention it publicly at its regular meeting Wednesday.

But Comptroller Peter Franchot (D), who is considering a run for governor, urged an Oct. 16 deadline to come up with a plan. Treasurer Nancy K. Kopp (D) immediately agreed.

“They need to be compensated as soon as possible,” Franchot said of Williams and four others whose attorneys have petitioned the state for a total of $12 million. “They were deprived of years of freedom, opportunity and time with their family and friends, and the very least we could do is compensate them in a timely and fair manner.”

[Meet the five innocent men seeking millions of dollars from Maryland]



Clockwise from top left: Walter Lomax, Hubert James Williams, Lamar Johnson and Clarence Shipley Jr. They and a fifth man, Jerome Johnson, are seeking $12 million from the state of Maryland after being imprisoned for a total of 120 years for crimes they did not commit. (Bonnie Jo Mount/The Washington Post)

Gov. Larry Hogan (R), who chairs the panel, was absent from the meeting and did not respond to a request for comment. His designee at the session, Lt. Gov. Boyd K. Rutherford, did not express an opinion on Franchot’s proposed timeline.

Maryland is among 35 states that permits payments to exonerees, but it has been among the slowest at approving them. The last exonerated prisoner to be compensated by the state was paid 15 years ago.

Williams, Lamar Johnson, Jerome Johnson, Walter Lomax and Clarence Shipley Jr. have been waiting as long as 19 months for the state to approve their petitions, which seek roughly $100,000 for each year they were wrongly imprisoned.

More than 10 weeks has passed since a joint letter from the men’s attorneys asked the state to “swiftly” negotiate and approve the compensation. Last month, 50 state lawmakers including House Speaker Adrienne A. Jones (D-Baltimore County) urged the panel to make a decision.

Under state law, the Board of Public Works has the power to determine and approve such awards for exonerees. But state lawmakers and Hogan, among others, have sought to establish a more formal process for deciding how much money should be allocated to the wrongly convicted.

The governor’s proposed plan for deciding compensation is expected next week, Franchot and others said. Hogan, who has said “there is no question that they deserve to be compensated,” blames Democrats in the General Assembly for not enacting legislation with specific guidelines on compensation. Lawmakers dismiss that critique as an attempt to avoid blame.

[Here’s how Maryland has paid exonerated prisoners in the past]

On Wednesday, without mentioning Williams by name, Rutherford said he had learned that morning that one of exonerees was hospitalized. He said the state was trying to secure a bed in a state substance abuse treatment facility and searching for a way to transport the exoneree there.

“We’re looking to see if there’s something we can do for one of the individuals who is suffering right now,” Rutherford said at the meeting.

Lawyers for Williams, who spent 11 years in prison for an attempted murder committed by someone else, said they were not notified of the state’s efforts to secure treatment for their client until contacted by a reporter.

The lawyers said Williams, who has long struggled with mental health and addiction problems, had been unreachable for about month before he was hospitalized with a head wound that required two stitches.

Williams was put on detoxification treatment and also is being treated for skin ulcers, a common ailment among inadequately clothed homeless people, the lawyers said.

They expect him to be discharged Friday — 12 days before the next Board of Public Works meeting, which is on Oct. 16.

“If James is released, then he’s most likely back on the streets, and he won’t resurface again until he’s in the hospital again,” attorney Andrew George said. “Even waiting until the next meeting isn’t going to cut it.”

Sitting in a room in Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Williams said he did not remember all of the details of the weekend assault but that he recalls being propelled forward, as if someone were pushing him from behind, when he stood to use the bathroom in the middle of the night. He said his memory then went dark, and he woke up in a hospital bed.

Williams spends most nights sleeping on park benches in Silver Spring, where he said he panhandles for money, asking strangers whether they can spare 50 cents for bus fare for a veteran. Saturday was the first night he said he had spent in City Plaza, which is where he was attacked.

“I don’t want to go back to that environment,” Williams said. “It’s caused me nothing but problems.”

Williams said he has sores on his body and needs a walker for his poor balance. But the walker he had received from Veterans Affairs was stolen from him, he said. He also said he has tried multiple rehabilitation programs but has always relapsed.



“I’ve burned myself out,” said Williams, adding that he knows he needs to get clean to avoid “drinking myself to death.”

He started choking up thinking about the possibility of being on the streets this winter, and remembering all the housing denials he has experienced. “I could freeze to death out there,” he said.
